newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish establishment keeps pressure on Islamists.
newsitem.headline: Turkish establishment keeps pressure on Islamists.

text.p: Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan was locked in a war of nerves with Turkey's political establishment on Thursday, one day before a meeting between top ministers and the staunchly secularist army brass.

The Hurriyet daily carried a front-page report -- dismissed as untrue by Erbakan and President Suleyman Demirel's office -- that Demirel had warned the Islamist-led coalition against threatening Turkey's "secularist, democratic (and) republican aims".
"If you continue with this attitude the regime will be in danger," the daily quoted the warning to Erbakan, the first Islamist leader of the officially secular republic.
Similar reports were carried in the rival Sabah newspaper. Both dailies are traditional organs of the secular political and business establishment.

Erbakan immediately denounced the reports as "a lie", and the president's press office denied any such letter was sent. However, the comments attributed to Demirel echo a series of recent briefings he gave to newspaper editors and columnists.
"Thankfully our government is working harmoniously. The censure motions helped to strengthen our government further," Erbakan later told reporters after talks with the president.
The government this week survived a censure motion challenge from two leftist parties who said the coalition was a threat to the country's secularism.

The reports aggravated political tensions, already running near fever pitch since the army sent tanks on manoeuvres through the Ankara district of Sincan on February 4 following an Islamist protest there attended by the Iranian ambassador.
The Foreign Ministry said on Thursday it was expelling Iran's consul to the eastern town of Erzurum, following his criticism of apparent anti-Iranian comments by a leading Turkish military official.
The announcement added to a diplomatic row between Tehran and Ankara, which protested to Iran earlier this month about the Iranian ambassador's comments at the Sincan rally.
Nightly civilian protests, launched initially against state corruption, have increasingly turned against Erbakan and his Islamist Welfare Party and show little sign of dying down.
"Ankara is in confusion. Ankara is tense. Ankara is doomed to give birth to many things," commentator Ismet Berkan wrote in the daily Radikal. "Ankara is full of rumour and speculation."
Such speculation is building toward Friday's regular session of the powerful National Security Council -- a vestige of earlier military rule -- that groups senior commanders and ministers.
Political analysts expect the council to issue a stern warning to Erbakan that mounting Islamist zeal threatens Turkey's secular and democratic institutions.
Few analysts, however, expect the kind of military intervention that twice before deposed then-prime minister Demirel.

"Those in Ankara who are in any way close to the military know that they have no intention of mounting a coup. They want to put pressure on the government to change its behaviour," commentator and author Mehmet Ali Birand told Reuters.
Birand, who has extensive contacts with the armed forces, suggested the soldiers might be contented if Erbakan agreed to jettison one or more of his more zealous ministers.
Financial markets, always volatile, closed off 1.48 percent as participants settled in to wait out the National Security Council session. Volume was moderate.
"The market is nervous. Nothing much can be expected until tomorrow's meeting is over," said on broker.
